column4: I want a good non-vim/emacs/nano editor for windows and linux that has macros and stuff like that.
apt-cache search 'code editor' for a list of candidates.
... Well, you eliminated the two principle candidates.
Visual Slickedit is a proprietary tool that a lot of folks like.
nedit and gedit have some coding support.  As I said:  most people likely use vim/emacs.
The essence of this problem is that it's yours not mine ;-)
does vim have support for doing fancy macros? Like textmate for mac?
Seriously, I just pipe something from shell.  There is also a record/playback feature, I don't use it.
how do you do the pipe?
To run on a range, say, defined as a & b:  :a,b! <cmd>
You can mark lines with the ' key.  So: 'a <move> 'b sets the marks 'a' and 'b'.  You can then do stuff (move, copy, pipe, etc.) on those marks.
